e.g. write the graphql here <https://github.com/siteminder-au/goldeneye/tree/develop/frontends/admin/src/views/hotels/update>
then it generates the types based on the graphql <https://github.com/siteminder-au/goldeneye/blob/develop/frontends/admin/src/services/gql/types.ts#L413>

the reason it was done because there are a lot of existing code that write the types by hand, when the graphql query changed, the types weren't sync or the types weren't correct in the first place. This avoids those issues from the beginning.
basically dev only need to write the .graphql files and graphql-codegen takes care the rest

<!here> vue-router@3.4.6 recently introduced a change to not to decode value in URLs <https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/dev/CHANGELOG.md> (<https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/pull/3323>)

e.g. before 3.4.6, for route `/pages/:token`, accessing URL `/pages/abc%3D` will set `this.$route.params.token` to `abc=`,
in 3.4.6, the value of `this.$route.params.token` will be `abc%3D`

This caused a breaking change in authx. Just sharing here in case this caused issues to other teams.

<!here> what’s everyone’s opinion on custom component tag conventions?  eg. for a component named AvailabilityCalendar, should it be written in the DOM as `<availability-calendar>` or `<AvailabilityCalendar>`

I’ve seen both in the wild… and I prefer the latter because of 2 reasons.
1. It matches the classname of the component, and also the filename (if you name your component files in this manner)
2. When looking at the DOM code, you can easily identify it as a non native element.

<@UJ9SWU674> has the same problem too. Suggest you guys put your heads together and maybe write up a quick doco because this comes all too often.

Here’s the advice I gave him:

```So audit issue 101 would be to upgrade to a version which solves the issue.

If there's no workaround to the issue (i.e. no patch version exists) then the next option is to white list the package in the audit script.

Here's an example inside of the platform-property/property-beef where it filters out a package. <https://github.com/siteminder-au/platform-property/blob/8c8440660bad2962ba8dd45aaac1902645d8cf5c/components/property-beef/package.json#L24>```
A more sledgehammer approach would be to disable the audit step in your buildkite pipeline. That obviously has some dangerous side affects so I recommend exhausting all other approaches first.

<@UKT9PNWR2> AFAIK there is no foolproof way to stop this behaviour, `format-detection` via a meta tag (which should be the right way) is ignored. You can either hide it as Will points out, use a HTML entities inside a <span> tag in an attempt to fool the parser or put the link text as an graphic/image (which may not display without user permission).

<@UKT9PNWR2> I’ve hit this before. If it’s purely an aesthetic requirement then beat the email client to it by making it a link then override the common changes to colour and text-decoration using an inline style tag. E.g.

```<a href="{{actionUrl}}" style="color:#000; text-decoration: none;">{{actionUrl}}</a>```
I am not sure if `<pre/>` is well supported in email clients.

Mornen everyone. There’s now a beta release of vue3 available: <https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next>

Package such as `vue-router`, `vue-test-utils` and a bunch of others are now in alpha, which a beta release around the corner. The general release date is still “sometime in 2020”… There’s definitely a lot more movement in the past week or so.

For anyone looking to try it out, they’ve released an experimental vue-cli plugin for adding vue3 support - <https://github.com/vuejs/vue-cli-plugin-vue-next>

You can still try out the `@vue/composition-api` package to extend an existing Vue2 app, which is what CMTBB and a couple of the apps in Insights are using today.

The main difference between those two sneakpeak options is the shift to ES6 Proxy in Vue3 as opposed to the get/set approach in Vue 2. If you’ve ever hit a reactivity problem in Vue2 and had to use `Vue.set(...)` to get around it, I recommend checking out this vid: <https://www.vuemastery.com/courses/advanced-components/evan-you-on-proxies/>

I was thinking for dev only. Actually I don't remember whether GraphQL Voyager reads GraphQL schema or introspection JSON.

Probably it's better to have a dx command e.g. `npx dx graphql-voyager git@github.com:siteminder-au/cm-core-api.git "src/main/resources/**/*.graphqls"`
Which fetch the Git repo to a temp folder and extract the GraphQLs, merge them, and run a local service e.g. at port 3000. Then the dev open `<http://localhost:3000>` to see it.

This way we don't need to have anything deployed and authentication is handled at local git level.

Just a proposal, I don't mean we need to do as I am not sure how many devs are using GraphQL Voyager.

You’d need to tweak how we handle authentication in all beefs. Because we handle authentication at the express layer the shared service would need to authenticate against each beef in order to load the introspection schema. A different approach would be to move authentication down a layer to the GraphQL server which means opening up the introspection schema to the world is easier. It’s important to note that this likely means exposing your GraphQL schema publicly, which raises eyebrows…

 I’m not against having that chat but I definitely can’t see the value to cost right now

Does anyone know if it's possible to create a subquery with SequelizeJS without writing raw query?

The problem I want to solve is to find properties that haven't been assigned to a given user.

I can use JOIN query.

```SELECT p.* FROM properties p
LEFT JOIN property_users ON property_users.property_id = p.id
LEFT JOIN users u ON u.id = property_users.user_id AND u.email = <mailto:'dul@nipdik.uz|'dul@nipdik.uz>'
WHERE p.enterprise_id = '37e4d063-92be-4e19-b054-eaa5094437c5' AND u.id IS NULL
LIMIT 0, 100;```
However, this is not possible with an existing SequelizeJS bug <https://github.com/sequelize/sequelize/issues/10962>

Another approach is to use sub query.

```SELECT p.* FROM proeprties p
WHERE p.enterprise_id = '37e4d063-92be-4e19-b054-eaa5094437c5' AND p.id NOT IN (
  SELECT assignedProperties.id FROM properties assignedProperties
  JOIN property_users ON property_users.property_id = assignedProperties.id
  JOIN users u ON u.id = property_users.user_id AND u.email = <mailto:'dul@nipdik.uz|'dul@nipdik.uz>'
)
LIMIT 0, 100;```
However, I couldn't find any docs to construct the request without writing raw query coz writing raw query would be more difficult to maintain.

Any help is appreciated.

I’ve done some research into how code splitting works in Sputnik and discovered that the previously documented method, didn’t explain how it worked or enable projects to utilise it

for instance, if you are doing this
```
import { SmCard } from '@siteminder/sputnik'
Vue.use(SmCard)
```
you’re going to import the whole Sputnik package anyway (unless you know how to configure tree shaking in your project correctly)

changing to this
```
import SmCard from '@siteminder/sputnik/lib/card'
Vue.use(SmCard)
```
will import the built `card` module only

Hi <!here>, You know how a lot of designers don’t like having the native blue focus ring around links/buttons when you click on them and you end up setting `outline:none`?

That is a really bad practice for accessibility.
I’ve found a nugget online to remedy this issue.  <https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nuclei/unfocus/master/dist/unfocus.js>

Just run this script as part of your app and it will set `outline:none` on mousedown, but remove it on keydown.  So that when the user tabs to your elements, they will see the focus ring when it exists.

Hi guild, does anyone have a favourite automated visual regression testing tool they would advocate for?

I'll be doing a evaluation of our options shortly. i.e. tooling to:
1.  tell us if we've changed the UI in a way users can see vs golden snapshots
2.  review any changes
3.  update snapshots

The most interesting use case would be changes to shared components, in those cases we'll need to
1. run all our visual regression tests,
2. check everything passes before the change (unless we know the test results are all up to date).
3. Apply the change,
4. rerun all the tests,
5. review all the changes and
6. hopefully accept and update all the golden snapshots.

yeah, I think we need to look at `SmTable` it’s not the enabler it should be

I’ve found some performance challenges with SmTable.

From memory I think we had a form inside of a table, or something inside there which was allowed to change the form’s `:model` prop.

Every-time the form took on an input event, the `:model` was updated and the entire table was re-rendered.
I think we could create a `lite` version of the table component that removes all of that javascript layouting and just exposes a native table styled by css
I have done it a few times where I end up rendering the table markup from within my vue app and just use the Sputnik style classes

I think this is a major shortcoming of the `SmTable` component, the javascript work it does for column sizing is not flexible
A standard table get’s it done properly

Has anyone found a way to make `SmTable` auto fit the content size? It looks like the element-ui@2.3.9 that Sputnik depends on only support evenly distribute the width or hard code the width by `width="180"`

1. Open up a subfolder (e.g. `frontends/admin`)
2. Select `File -> "Save Workspace As..."` to save the `.code-workspace` file somewhere
3. Select `File -> "Add Folder to Workspace..."` and add e.g. `components/admin-beef`

Hey everyone, just a heads up that we’ve published some changes to the guild’s RFC process. :all_the_things:

The changes cover a clearer process on “how to open and RFC” and improves visibility of the process doc by adding on the guild repo’s home page.

*The process can be found here:* <https://github.com/siteminder-au/guild-frontend/blob/master/artifacts/rfc-process.md>

Not sure if there’s an example out there <@U3P8YTKKL> but I’m think you have a couple of options (anyone else feel free to jump in with different approaches).

You could create another env for that feature in your dev config. E.g. `x-config-dev/x-frontend/x-feature` and deploy that, then in your mono-repo’s pipeline deploy that add a deploy command for that feature branch to deploy to that env.

Alternatively you could create an environment (as per the above) but instead of automating the deployment using your pipeline, you could run that command whenever you want to deploy a built package.

If you want some more context regarding those approaches you could take a look at a standard buildkite pipeline, which contains the command I mentioned and the logic for running a command for a certain branch: <https://github.com/siteminder-au/goldeneye/blob/develop/.buildkite/pipeline.yml#L34>

Hopefully that helps!

Heya, just sharing this here as I’ve had a few good questions lately about handling pluralisation in a Vue.js app.

Our frontends are shipped with Vue i18n as a standard. This module comes with a way of defining pluralised content which our translation team know how to handle.

The simplest usage is to define your translation source with three variants, `zero | singular | plural`.

E.g. `No apples | One apple | {count} apples`

For more info check it out here: <http://kazupon.github.io/vue-i18n/guide/pluralization.html#accessing-the-number-via-the-pre-defined-argument>

Also, if your app supports a slavic language, such as Russian or Ukrainian you may need to add some extra rules (it’s in the link above)

<!channel> There’s a an important gotcha with the platform header.
TLDR;
use `v-if` on `<sm-platform-header-dropdown>` and only make it `true` when you have both account menu options and hotel menu options ready for binding.

If you’re like me, who likes to use the arrow keys to move between items in a dropdown (and you should), then you will definitely want to know about this gotcha.

The platform header requires you to populate the menu items for Account menu options and Hotel menu options.  In Sputnik’s documentation, the example works because the items are hardcoded.  If your product’s menu items are dynamic, then you will need to implement the `<platform-header-dropdown>` so that it does not render until you have compiled the full list of items before binding it to the component.

Otherwise, el-dropdown will complain when resetting tab indices when arrow up/down or even when the dropdown loses focus.

In terms of the ground rules / guidelines, not everything is about tabbing.  :stuck_out_tongue:

The 3 biggest points I’d like to stress are:
1. Sputnik should be used for all front end implementations. If you can’t find a component or have problems with a component, reach out here.
2. You should always be working closely with your product designer before and during your implementation. This will save you time in the long run!
3. Test your code.  There’s plenty of Jesters here.  Reach out here or DM someone if you need help.
